learning_outcomes.description: Explain how sound is generated, transmitted, and measured.
Explain how humans hear and common causes of hearing impairment across the lifespan.
Describe how humans maintain balance and common causes of balance impairment across the lifespan.
Describe how humans receive and express speech and language, and common causes of speech and language impairment, across the lifespan.
Describe cognitive processes associated with hearing and common causes of cognitive impairment across the lifespan.

assessments.due_date:
17/03/2026 - 20/03/2026

The practical report must be submitted between 0800 on 17Mar26 and 1400 on 20Mar26.
assessments.task_description:
Within 4-days of completing the practical, students will complete a practical report involving calculations on key sound measures (decibels, pressure, intensity, frequency, wavelength, period, and speed) and the calibration of an audiometer.

To complete the practical report, students will:

1.     Open the AUDL7113 Course Blackboard site.

2.     Go to Assessment\\Assessment Task 1 - Practical Report.

3.     Open the practical report.

4.     Read the questions.

5.     Answer the questions in the answer boxes provided.

 The practical report will open at 0800 on the Tuesday following the practical & will close at 1400 on the Friday following the practical. Students may only complete the online test once during this 4-day window.

Once started, students will have two consecutive hours to complete the practical report although most students are expected to finish & submit within one hour. The report will automatically close & submit if the two-hour limit is reached.

It is strongly recommended that students complete the following steps before completing the practical report:

1.     Review all information presented in the practical manual.

2.     Review any personal notes taken during the practical.

3.     Review the relevant sections of the acoustics lecture notes.

4.     Review how to use your scientific calculator.

5.     Familiarise yourself with The University of Queensland’s Information Technology support service as the service you will contact if you experience IT issues while completing your practical report (webpage Contact AskUs including live chat & ask online services, phone +61 7 3346 4312, & video call UQ Service Centre - Video Kiosk).

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. As the task does not require students to reference their work, students are not required to reference any use of AI or MT on completing this task.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Once students have launched the practical report from within the AUDL7113 Course Blackboard site, they will be able to submit the report by clicking on the submit button at any time during its 2-hour time limit. The report will automatically close & submit if the two-hour limit is reached.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: An absolute penalty of 10% per day (or part thereof). For example, a score of 80% for a report submitted 25 hours late would be adjusted to 60% following an absolute penalty of 20% for the report being submitted 2-days (or part thereof) late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Tutorial 2 quiz 11/05/2026 3:00 pm

Tutorial 3 quiz 11/05/2026 5:00 pm

Each tutorial quiz is due immediately after its completion in class.
assessments.task_description:
Immediately following each tutorial, students will complete a short (15 minute), in-person in-class quiz. Each quiz will contain short-answer questions about a disorder found to be present in the tutorial's patient/client and the effects that disorder has on cellular anatomy and physiology.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. As the task does not require students to reference their work, students are not required to reference any use of AI or MT on completing this task.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit each tutorial quiz directly to the lecturer in class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam in AUDL7113 will contain a mix of question types including multiple choice, multiple answer, true/false, short answer and long answer questions addressing all topics covered in the lectures, practicals and problem-based learning activities. A full description of the exam can be found on the AUDL7113 Course Blackboard site.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial series

Tutorials will be held in-person on-campus in Week 8 (tutorial 1), 11 (tutorials 2 and 3) and 12 (tutorials 4 and 5) of semester. Each tutorial will run for 2-hours with tutorial 1 on disorders of the outer ear, tutorial 2 on disorders of the middle and inner ear, tutorial 3 on disorders of auditory nervous system and genetic disorders of hearing, tutorial 4 on disorders of balance, and tutorial 5 on disorders of the Facial Nerve. The tutorials are designed as experiential learning activities with students expected to have read the Tutorial Guide and the relevant section of the Disorders Notes before actively engaging with staff, students, and simulated patients in-class. As the tutorials are whole-class, interactive experiences, they will not be recorded or repeated.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series

Lectures will be held in-person on-campus in weeks 1-3 and 5-7 of semester. Each lecture will run for 4-hours with lectures examining acoustics, psychoacoustics, and anatomy and physiology of the auditory system. These lectures are designed as experiential learning activities with students expected to have read the relevant lecture notes before actively engaging with staff and students in-class but will also be recorded and uploaded to the AUDL7113 Course Blackboard site following each lecture.

Lectures will be held online as pre-recorded lectures in weeks 8-10 and 13 of semester. Each lecture will run for 2-4 hours with lectures introducing disorders and exploring embryology of the ear; anatomy and physiology of balance and the Facial Nerve; and anatomy, physiology and disorders of speech and language and cognition. These lectures can be viewed at any time but are best viewed in their scheduled semester week.

These lectures can be viewed at any time but are best viewed in their scheduled semester week.

learning_activities.topic:
Practical

A practical will be held in-person on-campus in week 4 of semester. This practical will run for 4-hours to provide students with hands-on experience using audiometers to generate sound, sound level meters to measure sound, and a sound level meter and artificial ear to calibrate an audiometer. The practical is designed as an experiential learning activity with students expected to have read the Practical Manual before actively engaging with staff, students, and audiometers, sound level meters, and artificial ears in-class. As the practical is a small-group, interactive experience, it will not be recorded or repeated.
